[L2377] s We can produce data intended to answer specific questions by observational
[L2378] studies or experiments. An observational study gathers data on individuals 
[L2379] as they are. Experiments actively do something to people, animals, or 
[L2380] objects in order to measure their response.
[L2381] s Statistical studies often try to show that changing one variable (the 
[L2382] explanatory variable) causes changes in another variable (the response
[L2383] variable). Variables are confounded when their effects on a response can’t 
[L2384] be distinguished from each other. Observational studies and uncontrolled 
[L2385] experiments often fail to show that changes in an explanatory variable 
[L2386] actually cause changes in a response variable because the explanatory 
[L2387] variable is confounded with lurking variables.
[L2388] s In an experiment, we impose one or more treatments on a group of experi￾mental units (sometimes called subjects if they are human). Each treatment 
[L2389] is a combination of values of the explanatory variables (also called factors).
[L2390] s The design of an experiment describes the choice of treatments and the 
[L2391] manner in which the subjects are assigned to the treatments. The basic 
[L2392] principles of experimental design are control for lurking variables, random 
[L2393] assignment of treatments, and replication (using enough experimental units).
[L2394] s The simplest form of control is comparison. Experiments should compare 
[L2395] two or more treatments to avoid confounding of the effect of a treatment 
[L2396] with other influences, such as lurking variables.
[L2397] s Random assignment uses chance to assign subjects to the treatments. 
[L2398] Random assignment creates treatment groups that are similar (except for 
[L2399] chance variation) before the treatments are applied. Randomization and 
[L2400] comparison together prevent bias, or systematic favoritism, in experiments.
[L2401] s Applying each treatment to many experimental units (replication)
[L2402] reduces the role of chance variation and makes the experiment more 
[L2403] likely to detect differences in the effects of the treatments.
[L2404] s Many behavioral and medical experiments are double-blind. That is, 
[L2405] neither the subjects nor those interacting with them and measuring their 
[L2406] responses know who is receiving which treatment. If one party knows and 
[L2407] the other doesn’t, then the experiment is single-blind.
[L2408] s Some experiments give a placebo (fake treatment) to a control group. 
[L2409] That helps prevent confounding due to the placebo effect, in which some 
[L2410] patients get better because they expect the treatment to work even though 
[L2411] they have received an inactive treatment.
[L2412] s In addition to comparison, a second form of control is to form blocks of 
[L2413] individuals that are similar in some way that is important to the response. 
[L2414] Randomization is then carried out separately within each block. Blocking 
[L2415] helps reduce unwanted variability among experimental units.
[L2416] s Matched pairs are a common form of blocking for comparing just two 
[L2417] treatments. In some matched pairs designs, each subject receives both 
[L2418] treatments in a random order. In others, the subjects are matched in pairs as 
[L2419] closely as possible, and each subject in a pair receives one of the treatments.

[L3216] Using Studies Wisely
[L3217] Researchers who conduct statistical studies often want to draw conclusions (make 
[L3218] inferences) that go beyond the data they produce. Here are two examples.
[L3219] sThe U.S. Census Bureau carries out a monthly Current Population Survey of 
[L3220] about 60,000 households. Their goal is to use data from these randomly selected 
[L3221] households to estimate the percent of unemployed individuals in the population.
[L3222] sScientists performed an experiment that randomly assigned 21 volunteer sub￾jects to one of two treatments: sleep deprivation for one night or unrestricted 
[L3223] sleep. The experimenters hoped to show that sleep deprivation causes a decrease 
[L3224] in performance two days later.48
[L3225] What type of inference can be made from a particular study? The answer depends 
[L3226] on the design of the study.
[L3227] Scope of Inference
[L3228] In the Census Bureau’s sample survey, the individuals who responded were cho￾sen at random from the population of interest. Random sampling avoids bias and 
[L3229] produces trustworthy estimates of the truth about the population. The Census 
[L3230] Bureau should be safe making an inference about the population based on the 
[L3231] results of the sample.
[L3232] In the sleep deprivation experiment, subjects were randomly assigned to the 
[L3233] sleep deprivation and unrestricted sleep treatments. Random assignment helps 
[L3234] ensure that the two groups of subjects are as similar as possible before the treat￾ments are imposed. If the unrestricted sleep group performs much better than 
[L3235] the sleep deprivation group, and the difference is too large to be explained by 
[L3236] chance variation in the random assignment, it must be due to the treatments. In 
[L3237] that case, the scientists could safely conclude that sleep deprivation caused the 
[L3238] decrease in performance. That is, they can make an inference about cause and 
[L3239] effect. However, since the experiment used volunteer subjects, this limits scien￾tists’ ability to generalize their findings to some larger population of individuals.

[L3245] Let’s recap what we’ve learned about the scope of inference in a statistical study. 
[L3246] Random selection of individuals allows inference about the population. Random 
[L3247] assignment of individuals to groups permits inference about cause and effect. The 
[L3248] chart below summarizes the possibilities.49
[L3249] Were individuals randomly assigned to groups?
[L3250] Yes No
[L3251] Were individuals 
[L3252] randomly selected?
[L3253] Yes
[L3254] Inference about the population: YES Inference about the population: YES
[L3255] Inference about cause and effect: YES Inference about cause and effect: NO
[L3256] No Inference about the population: NO Inference about the population: NO
[L3257] Inference about cause and effect: YES Inference about cause and effect: NO
[L3258] Well-designed experiments randomly assign individuals to treatment groups. 
[L3259] However, most experiments don’t select experimental units at random from the 
[L3260] larger population. That limits such experiments to inference about cause and 
[L3261] effect. Observational studies don’t randomly assign individuals to groups, which 
[L3262] rules out inference about cause and effect. An observational study that uses 
[L3263] random sampling can make an inference about the population. The following 
[L3264] example illustrates all four cases from the table above in a single setting.

[L3275] to take part in a study. Randomly assign half of them to take 500 mg of vitamin

[L3277] Design 3: Select a random sample of dental patients in town and get them to take 
[L3278] part in a study. Divide the patients into two groups as in Design 1.
[L3279] Design 4: Select a random sample of dental patients in town and get them to take

[L3316] The Challenges of 
[L3317] Establishing Causation
[L3318] A well-designed experiment tells us that changes in the explanatory variable cause 
[L3319] changes in the response variable. More precisely, it tells us that this happened 
[L3320] for specific individuals in the specific environment of this specific experiment. 
[L3321] The serious threat is that the treatments, the subjects, or the environment of our 
[L3322] experiment may not be realistic. Lack of realism can limit our ability to apply the 
[L3323] conclusions of an experiment to the settings of greatest interest.
[L3324] Do Center Brake Lights Reduce Rear-End Crashes?
[L3325] Lack of realism
[L3326] Do those high center brake lights, required on all cars sold in the United States 
[L3327] since 1986, really reduce rear-end collisions? Randomized comparative experi￾ments with fleets of rental and business cars, done before the lights were required, 
[L3328] showed that the third brake light reduced rear-end collisions by as much as 50%. 
[L3329] But requiring the third light in all cars led to only a 5% drop.
[L3330] What happened? Most cars did not have the extra brake light when the experi￾ments were carried out, so it caught the eye of following drivers. Now that almost 
[L3331] all cars have the third light, they no longer capture attention.

[L3389] Data Ethics*
[L3390] Medical professionals are taught to follow the basic principle “First, do no harm.” 
[L3391] Shouldn’t those who carry out statistical studies follow the same principle? Most 
[L3392] reasonable people think so. But this may not always be as simple as it sounds. De￾cide whether you think each of the following studies is ethical or unethical.
[L3393] sA promising new drug has been developed for treating cancer in humans. 
[L3394] Before giving the drug to human subjects, researchers want to administer the 
[L3395] drug to animals to see if there are any potentially serious side effects.
[L3396] sAre companies discriminating against some individuals in the hiring process? 
[L3397] To find out, researchers prepare several equivalent résumés for fictitious job 
[L3398] applicants, with the only difference being the gender of the applicant. They 
[L3399] send the fake résumés to companies advertising positions and keep track of the 
[L3400] number of males and females who are contacted for interviews.
[L3401] sIn a medical study of a new drug for migraine sufferers, volunteer subjects are 
[L3402] randomly assigned to two groups. Members of the first group are given a placebo 
[L3403] pill. Subjects in the second group are given the new drug. None of the subjects 
[L3404] knows whether they are taking a placebo or the active drug. Neither do any of 
[L3405] the physicians who are interacting with the subjects.
[L3406] sWill people try to stop someone from driving drunk? A television news pro￾gram hires an actor to play a drunk driver and uses a hidden camera to record the 
[L3407] behavior of individuals who encounter the driver.
[L3408] The most complex issues of data ethics arise when we collect data from people. 
[L3409] The ethical difficulties are more severe for experiments that impose some treatment 
[L3410] on people than for sample surveys that simply gather information. Trials of new 
[L3411] medical treatments, for example, can do harm as well as good to their subjects. Here 
[L3412] are some basic standards of data ethics that must be obeyed by all studies that gather 
[L3413] data from human subjects, both observational studies and experiments.
[L3414] Basic Data Ethics
[L3415] All planned studies must be reviewed in advance by an institutional review 
[L3416] board charged with protecting the safety and well-being of the subjects.
[L3417] All individuals who are subjects in a study must give their informed consent
[L3418] before data are collected.
[L3419] All individual data must be kept confidential. Only statistical summaries for 
[L3420] groups of subjects may be made public.

[L3426] Institutional review boards The purpose of an institutional review board is not 
[L3427] to decide whether a proposed study will produce valuable information or whether 
[L3428] it is statistically sound. The board’s purpose is, in the words of one university’s 
[L3429] board, “to protect the rights and welfare of human subjects (including patients) 
[L3430] recruited to participate in research activities.” The board reviews the plan of the 
[L3431] study and can require changes. It reviews the consent form to be sure that subjects 
[L3432] are informed about the nature of the study and about any potential risks. Once 
[L3433] research begins, the board monitors its progress at least once a year.

[L3494] s Most statistical studies aim to make inferences that go beyond the data 
[L3495] actually produced. Inference about the population requires that the 
[L3496] individuals taking part in a study be randomly selected from the larger 
[L3497] population. A well-designed experiment that randomly assigns treatments 
[L3498] to experimental units allows inference about cause and effect.
[L3499] s Lack of realism in an experiment can prevent us from generalizing its 
[L3500] results.
[L3501] s In the absence of an experiment, good evidence of causation requires 
[L3502] a strong association that appears consistently in many studies, a clear 
[L3503] explanation for the alleged causal link, and careful examination of possible 
[L3504] lurking variables.
[L3505] s Studies involving humans must be screened in advance by an institutional
[L3506] review board. All participants must give their informed consent before 
[L3507] taking part. Any information about the individuals in the study must be 
[L3508] kept confidential.
[L3509] s Remember that randomized comparative experiments can answer questions 
[L3510] that can’t be answered without them. Also remember that “the interests of 
[L3511] the subject must always prevail over the interests of science and society.”54

[L132] We often draw conclusions about a whole population on the

[L162] the school library and ask the first 30 students we see about their homework

[L164] easiest to reach is called a convenience sample. Convenience samples often

[L185] Choosing individuals who are easiest to reach results in a convenience sample.

[L196] DEFINITION: Bias
[L197] The design of a statistical study shows bias if it systematically favors certain outcomes.
[L198] Convenience samples are almost guaranteed to show bias. So are voluntary 
[L199] response samples, in which people decide whether to join the sample in response 
[L200] to an open invitation. Call-in, write-in, and many Internet polls rely on voluntary 
[L201] response samples. Unfortunately, people who choose to participate are usually 
[L202] not representative of any clearly defined population. Voluntary response samples 
[L203] attract people who feel strongly about the issue in question, often in the same 
[L204] direction. That leads to bias.
[L205] DEFINITION: Voluntary response sample
[L206] A voluntary response sample consists of people who choose themselves by respond￾ing to a general appeal. Voluntary response samples show bias because people with 
[L207] strong opinions (often in the same direction) are most likely to respond.
[L208] Write-in and call-in opinion polls are almost sure to lead to strong bias. In fact, 
[L209] only about 15% of the public has ever responded to a call-in poll, and these tend 
[L210] to be the same people who call radio talk shows. That’s not a representative sam￾ple of the population as a whole.

[L244] How to Sample Well: 
[L245] Random Sampling
[L246] In a voluntary response sample, people choose whether to respond. In a conve￾nience sample, the interviewer makes the choice. In both cases, personal choice 
[L247] produces bias. The statistician’s remedy is to allow impersonal chance to choose 
[L248] the sample. A sample chosen by chance rules out both favoritism by the sampler 
[L249] and self-selection by respondents. Random sampling, the use of chance to select 
[L250] a sample, is the central principle of statistical sampling.
[L251] The simplest way to use chance to select a sample is to place names in a hat 
[L252] (the population) and draw out a handful (the sample). This is the idea of a simple
[L253] random sample.
[L254] DEFINITION: Simple random sample
[L255] A simple random sample (SRS) of size n consists of n individuals from the population 
[L256] chosen in such a way that every set of n individuals has an equal chance to be the 
[L257] sample actually selected.
[L258] An SRS not only gives each indi￾vidual an equal chance to be chosen but 
[L259] also gives every possible sample an equal 
[L260] chance to be chosen. There are other 
[L261] random sampling methods that give 
[L262] each individual, but not each sample, an 
[L263] equal chance. Exercise 26 describes one 
[L264] such method. For now, let’s think about 
[L265] how to actually select an SRS.

[L267] drawing names from a hat to remind your￾self that an SRS doesn’t favor any part of the 
[L268] population. That’s why an SRS is a better 
[L269] method of choosing samples than conve￾nience or voluntary response samples. But 
[L270] writing names on slips of paper and draw￾ing them from a hat doesn’t work as well

[L292] How to Choose an SRS Using Table D
[L293] STEP 1: LABEL. Give each member of the population a numerical label of the 
[L294] same length.
[L295] STEP 2: TABLE. Read consecutive groups of digits of the appropriate length 
[L296] from Table D.
[L297] Your sample contains the individuals whose labels you find.
[L298] Always use the shortest labels that will cover your population. For instance, 
[L299] you can label up to 100 individuals with two digits: 01, 02, . . . , 99, 00. As 
[L300] standard practice, we recommend that you begin with label 1 (or 01 or 001, as 
[L301] needed). Reading groups of digits from the table gives all individuals the same 
[L302] chance to be chosen because all labels of the same length have the same chance 
[L303] to be found in the table. For example, any pair of digits in the table is equally 
[L304] likely to be any of the 100 possible labels 01, 02, . . . , 99, 00. Ignore any group of 
[L305] digits that was not used as a label or that duplicates a label already in the sample. 
[L306] You can read digits from Table D in any order—across a row, down a column, 
[L307] and so on—because the table has no order. We recommend reading across rows 
[L308] from left to right.

[L406] Other Sampling Methods
[L407] The basic idea of sampling is straightforward: take an SRS from the population 
[L408] and use your sample results to gain information about the population. Unfor￾tunately, it’s usually very difficult to actually get an SRS from the population of 
[L409] interest. Imagine trying to get a simple random sample of all the batteries pro￾duced in one day at a factory. Or an SRS of all U.S. high school students. In either 
[L410] case, it’s just not practical to choose an SRS. For starters, it would be difficult to 
[L411] obtain an accurate list of the population from which to draw the sample. It would 
[L412] also be very time-consuming to collect data from each individual that’s randomly 
[L413] selected. Sometimes, there are also statistical advantages to using more complex 
[L414] sampling methods.

[L418] One of the most common alternatives to an SRS involves sampling important 
[L419] groups (called strata) within the population separately. Then these separate “sub￾samples” are combined to form one stratified random sample. This method 
[L420] works best when the individuals within each stratum are similar to one another 
[L421] in a way that affects the variable being measured but there are large differences 
[L422] between strata.
[L423] DEFINITION: Stratified random sample and strata
[L424] To select a stratified random sample, first classify the population into groups of similar 
[L425] individuals, called strata. Then choose a separate SRS in each stratum and combine 
[L426] these SRSs to form the full sample.
[L427] Choose the strata based on facts known before the sample is taken. For example, 
[L428] in a study of sleep habits on school nights, the population of students in a large 
[L429] high school might be divided into freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior stra￾ta. In a preelection poll, a population of election districts might be divided into 
[L430] urban, suburban, and rural strata. If the individuals in each stratum are less varied 
[L431] than the population as a whole, a stratified random sample can produce better in￾formation about the population than an SRS of the same size. Not convinced? Try 
[L432] the following Activity.

[L494] clusters should mirror the characteristics of the population. Then choose an SRS of the 
[L495] clusters. All individuals in the chosen clusters are included in the sample.

[L664] Inference for Sampling
[L665] The purpose of a sample is to give us information about a larger population. The 
[L666] process of drawing conclusions about a population on the basis of sample data is 
[L667] called inference because we infer information about the population from what 
[L668] we know about the sample. Inference from convenience samples or voluntary 
[L669] response samples would be misleading because these methods of choosing a sam￾ple are biased. We are almost certain that the sample does not fairly represent 
[L670] the population. The first reason to rely on random sampling is to eliminate bias in 
[L671] selecting samples from the list of available individuals.
[L672] Still, it is unlikely that results from a random sample are exactly the same as for 
[L673] the entire population. Sample results, like the unemployment rate obtained from 
[L674] the monthly Current Population Survey, are only estimates of the truth about the 
[L675] population. If we select two samples at random from the same population, we will 
[L676] almost certainly choose different individuals. So the sample results will differ some￾what, just by chance. Properly designed samples avoid systematic bias. But their re￾sults are rarely exactly correct, and we expect them to vary from sample to sample.
[L677] Inference

[L691] Why can we trust random samples? As the previous Activity illustrates, the 
[L692] results of random sampling don’t change haphazardly from sample to sample. 
[L693] Because we deliberately use chance, the results obey the laws of probability that 
[L694] govern chance behavior. These laws allow us to say how likely it is that sample 
[L695] results are close to the truth about the population. The second reason to use 
[L696] random sampling is that the laws of probability allow trustworthy inference about 
[L697] the population. Results from random samples come with a margin of error that 
[L698] sets bounds on the size of the likely error. We will discuss the details of inference 
[L699] for sampling later.
[L700] One point is worth making now: larger random samples give better informa￾tion about the population than smaller samples. For instance, in the Activity, 
[L701] you would get a better estimate of the proportion of red chips in the popula￾Margin of error

[L704] Section 4.1 Sampling and Surveys 221
[L705] tion using random samples of 40 chips than 20 chips. By taking a very large 
[L706] sample, you can be confident that the sample result is very close to the truth 
[L707] about the population.
[L708] The Current Population Survey contacts about 60,000 households, so we’d 
[L709] expect its estimate of the national unemployment rate to be within about 0.1% 
[L710] of the actual population value. Opinion polls that contact 1000 or 1500 peo￾ple give less precise results—we expect the sample result to be within about 
[L711] 3% of the actual population percent with a given opinion. Of course, only 
[L712] samples chosen by chance carry this guarantee. Lou Dobbs’s online sample 
[L713] tells us little about overall American public opinion even though 7350 people 
[L714] clicked a response.
[L715] Sample Surveys: What Can Go Wrong?
[L716] Random sampling eliminates bias in choosing a sample. But even a large ran￾dom sample will give a result that differs from the truth about the population. 
[L717] This “sampling variability” is described by the margin of error that comes with 
[L718] most poll results. So once we see the magic words randomly selected, do we 
[L719] know we have trustworthy information? It certainly beats voluntary response, 
[L720] but not always by as much as we might hope. Sampling in the real world is 
[L721] more complex and less reliable than choosing an SRS from a list of names in 
[L722] a textbook exercise.
[L723] Most sample surveys are affected by errors in addition to sampling variabil￾ity. These errors can introduce bias that makes a survey result meaningless. 
[L724] Good sampling technique includes the art of reducing all sources of error. 
[L725] Let’s look at the two main sources of errors in sample surveys: sampling errors 
[L726] and nonsampling errors.
[L727] Sampling errors The margin of error tells us how much sampling variability to 
[L728] expect, and we can control it by choosing the size of our random sample. It doesn’t 
[L729] tell us about sampling errors, mistakes made in the process of taking a sample that 
[L730] could lead to inaccurate information about the population. One source of sam￾pling error is the use of bad sampling methods, such as voluntary response. We 
[L731] can avoid bad methods. Other sampling errors are not so easy to handle. Sampling 
[L732] often begins with a list of individuals from which we will draw our sample. This 
[L733] list is called the sampling frame. Ideally, the sampling frame should list every 
[L734] individual in the population. Because a list of the entire population is rarely avail￾able, most samples suffer from some degree of undercoverage.
[L735] DEFINITION: Undercoverage
[L736] Undercoverage occurs when some groups in the population are left out of the process 
[L737] of choosing the sample.
[L738] A sample survey of households, for example, will miss not only homeless peo￾ple but prison inmates and students in dormitories. An opinion poll conducted 
[L739] by calling landline telephone numbers will miss households that have only cell 
[L740] phones as well as households without a phone. The results of national sample 
[L741] surveys therefore have some bias due to undercoverage if the people not covered 
[L742] differ systematically from the rest of the population.

[L748] Sampling errors in careful sample surveys are usually quite small. The real 
[L749] problems start when someone picks up (or doesn’t pick up) the phone. Now non￾sampling errors take over.
[L750] Nonsampling errors Nonsampling errors are those that can plague even a census. 
[L751] One of the most serious sources of bias in sample surveys is nonresponse, which 
[L752] occurs when a selected individual cannot be contacted or refuses to cooperate. 
[L753] Nonresponse to sample surveys often exceeds 50%, even with careful planning and 
[L754] several callbacks. Because nonresponse is higher in urban areas, most sample sur￾veys substitute other people in the same area to avoid favoring rural areas in the 
[L755] final sample. If the people contacted differ from those who are rarely at home or 
[L756] who refuse to answer questions, some bias remains. For example, retired people 
[L757] may be more likely to respond, which would give their opinions more weight. In 
[L758] a poll about Social Security reform, this could give a misleading impression of the 
[L759] population’s views.
[L760] DEFINITION: Nonresponse
[L761] Nonresponse occurs when an individual chosen for the sample can’t be contacted or 
[L762] refuses to participate.
[L763] Some students misuse the term “voluntary response” to explain why cer￾tain individuals don’t respond in a sample survey. Their idea is that par￾ticipation in the survey is optional (voluntary), so anyone can refuse to 
[L764] take part. What the students are actually describing is nonresponse. Think about 
[L765] it this way: nonresponse can occur only after a sample has been selected. In a 
[L766] voluntary response sample, every individual has opted to take part, so there won’t 
[L767] be any nonresponse.
[L768] The ACS, GSS, and Opinion Polls
[L769] How bad is nonresponse?
[L770] The Census Bureau’s American Community Survey (ACS) has the lowest nonre￾sponse rate of any poll we know: only about 1% of the households in the sample 
[L771] refuse to respond. The overall nonresponse rate, including “never at home” and 
[L772] other causes, is just 2.5%.8 This monthly survey of about 250,000 households 
[L773] replaces the “long form” that in the past was sent to some households in the every￾ten-years national census. Participation in the ACS is mandatory, and the Census 
[L774] Bureau follows up by telephone and then in person if a household doesn’t return 
[L775] the mail questionnaire.
[L776] The University of Chicago’s General Social Survey (GSS) is the nation’s most 
[L777] important social science survey (see Figure 4.2). The GSS contacts its sample 
[L778] in person, and it is run by a university. Despite these advantages, its most recent 
[L779] survey had a 30% rate of nonresponse.

[L789] busy schedules, skepticism and outright refusals, interviews were completed 
[L790] in just 38% of households that were reached.” Combining households that 
[L791] could not be contacted with those who did not complete the interview gave 
[L792] a nonresponse rate of 73%.9
[L793] Another type of nonsampling error occurs when someone gives an incorrect 
[L794] response. A systematic pattern of incorrect responses in a sample survey leads 
[L795] to response bias. People know that they should take the trouble to vote, for 
[L796] example, so many who didn’t vote in the last election will tell an interviewer 
[L797] that they did. The race or gender of the interviewer can influence responses to 
[L798] questions about race relations or attitudes toward feminism. Answers to ques￾tions that ask people to recall past events are often inaccurate because of faulty 
[L799] memory. “Have you visited a dentist in the last 6 months?” will often draw a 
[L800] “Yes” from someone who last visited a dentist 8 months ago.10 Careful training 
[L801] of interviewers and careful supervision to avoid variation among the interview￾ers can reduce response bias. Good interviewing technique is another aspect of 
[L802] a well-done sample survey.

[L807] The wording of questions is the most important influence on the answers given 
[L808] to a sample survey. Confusing or leading questions can introduce strong bias, and 
[L809] changes in wording can greatly change a survey’s outcome. Even the order in 
[L810] which questions are asked matters.
[L811] How Do Americans Feel about Illegal Immigrants?
[L812] Question wording matters
[L813] “Should illegal immigrants be prosecuted and deported for being in the U.S. illegally, 
[L814] or shouldn’t they?” Asked this question in an opinion poll, 69% favored deportation. 
[L815] But when the very same sample was asked whether illegal immigrants who have 
[L816] worked in the United States for two years “should be given a chance to keep their jobs 
[L817] and eventually apply for legal status,” 62% said that they should. Different questions 
[L818] give quite different impressions of attitudes toward illegal immigrants.
[L819] Don’t trust the results of a sample survey until you have read the exact questions 
[L820] asked. The amount of nonresponse and the date of the survey are also impor￾tant. Good statistical design is a part, but only a part, of a trustworthy survey.
[L821] Does the order matter? Ask a sample of college students these two questions:
[L822] “How happy are you with your life in general?” (Answers on a scale of 1 to 5)
[L823] “How many dates did you have last month?”
[L824] There is almost no association between responses to the two questions when asked 
[L825] in this order. It appears that dating has little to do with happiness. Reverse the order 
[L826] of the questions, however, and a much stronger association appears: college students 
[L827] who say they had more dates tend to give higher ratings of happiness about life. Asking 
[L828] a question that brings dating to mind makes dating success a big factor in happiness.

[L847] EXAMPLE

[L850] s A sample survey selects a sample from the population of all individuals 
[L851] about which we desire information. We base conclusions about the 
[L852] population on data from the sample. It is important to specify exactly what 
[L853] population you are interested in and what variables you will measure.
[L854] s Random sampling uses chance to select a sample.
[L855] s The basic random sampling method is a simple random sample (SRS).
[L856] An SRS gives every possible sample of a given size the same chance to be 
[L857] chosen. Choose an SRS by labeling the members of the population and 
[L858] using random digits to select the sample. Technology can automate this 
[L859] process.
[L860] s To choose a stratified random sample, divide the population into strata,
[L861] groups of individuals that are similar in some way that might affect their 
[L862] responses. Then choose a separate SRS from each stratum.
[L863] s To choose a cluster sample, divide the population into groups, or clusters.
[L864] Randomly select some of these clusters. All the individuals in the chosen 
[L865] clusters are included in the sample.
[L866] s Failure to use random sampling often results in bias, or systematic errors in 
[L867] the way the sample represents the population. Voluntary response samples,
[L868] in which the respondents choose themselves, and convenience samples,
[L869] in which individuals close by are included in the sample, are particularly 
[L870] prone to large bias.
[L871] s Sampling errors come from the act of choosing a sample. Random 
[L872] sampling error and undercoverage are common types of sampling error. 
[L873] Undercoverage occurs when some members of the population are left out of 
[L874] the sampling frame, the list from which the sample is actually chosen.
[L875] s The most serious errors in most careful surveys, however, are nonsampling
[L876] errors. These have nothing to do with choosing a sample—they are 
[L877] present even in a census. The single biggest problem for sample surveys 
[L878] is nonresponse: people can’t be contacted or refuse to answer. Incorrect 
[L879] answers by respondents can lead to response bias. Finally, the exact 
[L880] wording of questions has a big influence on the answers.

[L1404] Experiments
[L1405] A sample survey aims to gather information about a population without disturb￾ing the population in the process. Sample surveys are one kind of observational
[L1406] study. Other observational studies watch the behavior of animals in the wild or the 
[L1407] interactions between teacher and students in the classroom. This section is about 
[L1408] statistical designs for experiments, a very different way to produce data.
[L1409] Observational Study versus Experiment
[L1410] In contrast to observational studies, experiments don’t just observe individuals or 
[L1411] ask them questions. They actively impose some treatment in order to measure the 
[L1412] response. Experiments can answer questions like “Does aspirin reduce the chance 
[L1413] of a heart attack?” and “Can yoga help dogs live longer?”
[L1414] DEFINITION: Observational study and experiment
[L1415] An observational study observes individuals and measures variables of interest but 
[L1416] does not attempt to influence the responses.
[L1417] An experiment deliberately imposes some treatment on individuals to measure their 
[L1418] responses.
[L1419] The goal of an observational study can be to describe some group or situation, 
[L1420] to compare groups, or to examine relationships between variables. The purpose 
[L1421] of an experiment is to determine whether the treatment causes a change in the 
[L1422] response. An observational study, even one based on a random sample, is a poor 
[L1423] way to gauge the effect that changes in one variable have on another variable. To 
[L1424] see the response to a change, we must actually impose the change. When our goal 
[L1425] is to understand cause and effect, experiments are the only source of fully convincing 
[L1426] data. For this reason, the distinction between observational study and experiment 
[L1427] is one of the most important in statistics.

[L1464] To get convincing data on the link between hormone replacement and heart 
[L1465] attacks, we should do an experiment. Experiments don’t let women decide what 
[L1466] to do. They assign women to either hormone replacement or to dummy pills that 
[L1467] look and taste the same as the hormone pills. The assignment is done by a coin 
[L1468] toss, so that all kinds of women are equally likely to get either treatment. By 2002, 
[L1469] several experiments with women of different ages agreed that hormone replace￾ment does not reduce the risk of heart attacks. The National Institutes of Health, 
[L1470] after reviewing the evidence, concluded that the first studies were wrong. Taking 
[L1471] hormones after menopause quickly fell out of favor.18
[L1472] For each of these studies, the explanatory variable was whether a woman took 
[L1473] hormones, and the response variable was whether the woman had a heart attack. 
[L1474] Researchers wanted to argue that changes in the explanatory variable (taking hor￾mones or not) actually caused changes in the response variable (having a heart 
[L1475] attack or not). In the early observational studies, however, the effect of taking 
[L1476] hormones was mixed up with the characteristics of women who chose to take 
[L1477] them. These characteristics are lurking variables that make it hard to see the true 
[L1478] relationship between the explanatory and response variables.
[L1479] DEFINITION: Lurking variable
[L1480] A lurking variable is a variable that is not among the explanatory or response variables 
[L1481] in a study but that may influence the response variable.
[L1482] Let’s consider two lurking variables from the observational studies of hormone 
[L1483] replacement: number of doctor visits per year and age. The women who chose to
[L1484] take hormones visited their doctors more often than the women who didn’t take 
[L1485] hormones. Did the women in the hormone group have fewer heart attacks because
[L1486] they got better health care or because they took hormones? We can’t be sure. 
[L1487] A situation like this, in which the effects of two variables on a response variable
[L1488] cannot be separated from each other, is called confounding.
[L1489] What about age? Older women are at greater risk of having a heart attack than 
[L1490] younger women. If the women who took hormones were generally younger than 
[L1491] those who didn’t, we’d have more confounding. That wasn’t the case, however. 
[L1492] There was no link between age and group membership (hormones or not) in the 
[L1493] observational studies. With no association between the lurking variable and the 
[L1494] explanatory variable, there can be no confounding.
[L1495] DEFINITION: Confounding
[L1496] Confounding occurs when two variables are associated in such a way that their effects 
[L1497] on a response variable cannot be distinguished from each other.

[L1500] Section 4.2 Experiments 233
[L1501] Observational studies of the effect of one variable on another often fail 
[L1502] because of confounding between the explanatory variable and one or more 
[L1503] lurking variables. Well-designed experiments take steps to prevent con￾founding. The later hormone therapy experiments avoided confounding by letting 
[L1504] chance decide who took hormones and who didn’t. That way, women who took 
[L1505] better care of themselves were split about evenly between the two groups. So were 
[L1506] older women and younger women. When these experiments found no reduction 
[L1507] in heart attack risk for women taking hormones, researchers began to doubt the 
[L1508] results of the earlier observational studies. The moral of the story is simple: beware 
[L1509] the lurking variable!

[L1524] The Language of Experiments
[L1525] An experiment is a statistical study in which we actually do something (a treat￾ment) to people, animals, or objects (the experimental units) to observe the re￾sponse. Here is the basic vocabulary of experiments.
[L1526] DEFINITION: Treatment, experimental units, subjects
[L1527] A specific condition applied to the individuals in an experiment is called a treatment.
[L1528] If an experiment has several explanatory variables, a treatment is a combination of 
[L1529] specific values of these variables.
[L1530] The experimental units are the smallest collection of individuals to which treatments 
[L1531] are applied. When the units are human beings, they often are called subjects.
[L1532] The best way to learn the language of experiments is to practice using it.

[L1548] Vocabulary of experiments
[L1549] Researchers at the University of North Carolina were concerned about the 
[L1550] increasing dropout rate in the state’s high schools, especially for low-income stu￾dents. Surveys of recent dropouts revealed that many of these students had

[L1552] To change this perception, researchers developed a program called Ca￾reerStart. The big idea of the program is that teachers show students how 
[L1553] the topics they learn get used in specific careers.
[L1554] To test the effectiveness of CareerStart, the researchers recruited 14 mid￾dle schools in Forsyth County to participate in an experiment. Seven of 
[L1555] the schools, chosen at random, used CareerStart along with the district’s 
[L1556] standard curriculum. The other seven schools just followed the standard 
[L1557] curriculum. Researchers followed both groups of students for several 
[L1558] years, collecting data on students’ attendance, behavior, standardized test 
[L1559] scores, level of engagement in school, and whether the students graduated from 
[L1560] high school. Results: Students at schools that used CareerStart generally had bet￾ter attendance and fewer discipline problems, earned higher test scores, reported 
[L1561] greater engagement in their classes, and were more likely to graduate.20
[L1562] PROBLEM: Identify the experimental units, explanatory and response variables, and the treatments 
[L1563] in the CareerStart experiment.
[L1564] SOLUTION: Theexperimental units are 14 middle schools in Forsyth County, NC. Theexplanatory 
[L1565] variable is whether the school used the CareerStart program with its students. This experiment

[L1567] behavior, student engagement, and graduation rates.
[L1568] The previous example illustrates the big advantage of experiments over obser￾vational studies: experiments can give good evidence for causation. In an experi￾ment, we study the effects of the specific treatments we are interested in, while 
[L1569] trying to control for the effect of lurking variables. For instance, the students in 
[L1570] all 14 schools followed the standard curriculum. To ensure that the two groups 
[L1571] of schools were as similar as possible before the treatments were administered, 
[L1572] researchers let chance decide which 7 schools would use CareerStart. The only 
[L1573] systematic difference between the schools was the educational treatment. When 
[L1574] students from the CareerStart schools did better, we can be confident that the 
[L1575] program made the difference.

[L1616] How to Experiment Badly 
[L1617] Experiments are the preferred method for examining the effect of one variable on 
[L1618] another. By imposing the specific treatment of interest and controlling other 
[L1619] influences, we can pin down cause and effect. Good designs are essential for 
[L1620] effective experiments, just as they are for sampling. To see why, let’s start with an 
[L1621] example of a bad experimental design.

[L1744] DEFINITION: Completely randomized design
[L1745] In a completely randomized design, the treatments are assigned to all the experimen￾tal units completely by chance.
[L1746] Notice that the definition of a completely randomized design does not require 
[L1747] that each treatment be assigned to an equal number of experimental units. It does 
[L1748] specify that the assignment of treatments must occur completely at random.
[L1749] Does using chance to assign treatments in an experiment guarantee a 
[L1750] completely randomized design? Actually, no. Let’s return to the SAT prep 
[L1751] course experiment involving 50 students. Another way to randomly assign the sub￾jects to the two treatments is by tossing a coin. Have each student come forward 
[L1752] and toss a coin. If it’s heads, then the student will take the course online. If it’s 
[L1753] tails, then the student will take the classroom course.
[L1754] As long as all 50 students toss a coin, this is still a completely randomized design.
[L1755] Of course, the two experimental groups are unlikely to contain exactly 25 students 
[L1756] each due to the chance variation in coin tosses.
[L1757] The problem comes if we try to force the two groups to have equal sizes. Sup￾pose we let the coin tossing continue until one of the groups has 25 students and 
[L1758] then place the remaining students in the other group. This is no longer a com￾pletely randomized design, because the last few students aren’t being assigned 
[L1759] to one of the treatments by chance. In fact, these students will all end up in the 
[L1760] same group, which could lead to bias if these individuals share some character￾istic that would systematically affect the response variable. For example, if the 
[L1761] students came to toss the coin last because they’re lazier than the other students 
[L1762] who volunteered, then the SAT prep class that they’re in will seem less effective 
[L1763] than it really is.

[L1906] Summary: Principles of Experimental Design
[L1907] The basic principles for designing experiments are as follows:
[L1908] 1. Control for lurking variables that might affect the response: Use a com￾parative design and ensure that the only systematic difference between the 
[L1909] groups is the treatment administered.
[L1910] 2. Random assignment: Use impersonal chance to assign experimental 
[L1911] units to treatments. This helps create roughly equivalent groups of ex￾perimental units by balancing the effects of lurking variables that aren’t 
[L1912] controlled on the treatment groups.
[L1913] 3. Replication: Use enough experimental units in each group so that any 
[L1914] differences in the effects of the treatments can be distinguished from 
[L1915] chance differences between the groups.

[L1983] Do placebos work?
[L1984] Want to help balding men keep their hair? Give them a placebo—one study found 
[L1985] that 42% of balding men maintained or increased the amount of hair on their 
[L1986] heads when they took a placebo. In another study, researchers zapped the wrists of 
[L1987] 24 test subjects with a painful jolt of electricity. Then they rubbed a cream with no 
[L1988] active medicine on subjects’ wrists and told them the cream should help soothe 
[L1989] the pain. When researchers shocked them again, 8 subjects said they experienced 
[L1990] significantly less pain.24
[L1991] When the ailment is vague and psychological, like depression, some experts think 
[L1992] that about three-quarters of the effect of the most widely used drugs is just the 
[L1993] placebo effect.25 Others disagree. The strength of the placebo effect in medical 
[L1994] treatments is hard to pin down because it depends on the exact environment. How 
[L1995] enthusiastic the doctor is seems to matter a lot. But “placebos work” is a good 
[L1996] place to start when you think about planning medical experiments.
[L1997] The strength of the placebo effect is a strong argument for randomized compara￾tive experiments. In the baldness study, 42% of the placebo group kept or increased 
[L1998] their hair, but 86% of the men getting a new drug to fight baldness did so. The drug 
[L1999] beats the placebo, so it has something besides the placebo effect going for it. Of 
[L2000] course, the placebo effect is still part of the reason this and other treatments work.
[L2001] Because the placebo effect is so strong, it would be foolish to tell subjects in a 
[L2002] medical experiment whether they are receiving a new drug or a placebo. Knowing 
[L2003] that they are getting “just a placebo” might weaken the placebo effect and bias the 
[L2004] experiment in favor of the other treatments. It is also foolish to tell doctors and 
[L2005] other medical personnel what treatment each subject received. If they know that a 
[L2006] subject is getting “just a placebo,” they may expect less than if they know the sub￾ject is receiving a promising experimental drug. Doctors’ expectations change how 
[L2007] they interact with patients and even the way they diagnose a patient’s condition. 
[L2008] Whenever possible, experiments with human subjects should be double-blind.

[L2035] Inference for Experiments
[L2036] In an experiment, researchers usually hope to see a difference in the responses so 
[L2037] large that it is unlikely to happen just because of chance variation. We can use the 
[L2038] laws of probability, which describe chance behavior, to learn whether the treat￾ment effects are larger than we would expect to see if only chance were operating. 
[L2039] If they are, we call them statistically significant.
[L2040] DEFINITION: Statistically significant
[L2041] An observed effect so large that it would rarely occur by chance is called statistically 
[L2042] significant.
[L2043] If we observe statistically significant differences among the groups in a random￾ized comparative experiment, we have good evidence that the treatments actually 
[L2044] caused these differences. You will often see the phrase “statistically significant” in 
[L2045] published research reports in many fields. The great advantage of randomized com￾parative experiments is that they can produce data that give good evidence for a 
[L2046] cause-and-effect relationship between the explanatory and response variables. We 
[L2047] know that in general a strong association does not imply causation. A statistically sig￾nificant association in data from a well-designed experiment does imply causation.

[L2176] DEFINITION: Block and randomized block design
[L2177] A block is a group of experimental units that are known before the experiment to be 
[L2178] similar in some way that is expected to affect the response to the treatments.
[L2179] In a randomized block design, the random assignment of experimental units to treat￾ments is carried out separately within each block.
[L2180] Blocks are another form of control. They control the effects of some outside 
[L2181] variables by bringing those variables into the experiment to form the blocks. 
[L2182] A randomized block design allows us to draw separate conclusions about each 
[L2183] block, for example, about light-colored and dark-colored clothes in the laundry 
[L2184] experiment. Blocking also allows more precise overall conclusions, because the

[L2188] systematic differences between light- and dark-colored clothes can be removed 
[L2189] when we study the overall effects of using this detergent in warm and cold 
[L2190] water.
[L2191] The idea of blocking is an important additional principle of experimental 
[L2192] design. A wise experimenter will form blocks based on the most important un￾avoidable sources of variability (lurking variables) among the experimental units. 
[L2193] Randomization will then average out the effects of the remaining lurking vari￾ables and allow an unbiased comparison of the treatments. The moral of the story 
[L2194] is: control what you can, block on what you can’t control, and randomize to create 
[L2195] comparable groups.

[L2259] Matched Pairs Design
[L2260] A common type of randomized block design for comparing two treatments is a 
[L2261] matched pairs design. The idea is to create blocks by matching pairs of similar 
[L2262] experimental units. Then we can use chance to decide which member of a pair 
[L2263] gets the first treatment. The other subject in that pair gets the other treatment. 
[L2264] That is, the random assignment of subjects to treatments is done within each 
[L2265] matched pair. Just as with other forms of blocking, matching helps reduce the 
[L2266] effect of variation among the experimental units.
[L2267] Sometimes each “pair” in a matched pairs design consists of just one experi￾mental unit that gets both treatments one after the other. In that case, each experi￾mental unit serves as its own control. The order of the treatments can influence 
[L2268] the response, so we randomize the order for each experimental unit.

[L2377] s We can produce data intended to answer specific questions by observational
[L2378] studies or experiments. An observational study gathers data on individuals 
[L2379] as they are. Experiments actively do something to people, animals, or 
[L2380] objects in order to measure their response.
[L2381] s Statistical studies often try to show that changing one variable (the 
[L2382] explanatory variable) causes changes in another variable (the response
[L2383] variable). Variables are confounded when their effects on a response can’t 
[L2384] be distinguished from each other. Observational studies and uncontrolled 
[L2385] experiments often fail to show that changes in an explanatory variable 
[L2386] actually cause changes in a response variable because the explanatory 
[L2387] variable is confounded with lurking variables.
[L2388] s In an experiment, we impose one or more treatments on a group of experi￾mental units (sometimes called subjects if they are human). Each treatment 
[L2389] is a combination of values of the explanatory variables (also called factors).
[L2390] s The design of an experiment describes the choice of treatments and the 
[L2391] manner in which the subjects are assigned to the treatments. The basic 
[L2392] principles of experimental design are control for lurking variables, random 
[L2393] assignment of treatments, and replication (using enough experimental units).
[L2394] s The simplest form of control is comparison. Experiments should compare 
[L2395] two or more treatments to avoid confounding of the effect of a treatment 
[L2396] with other influences, such as lurking variables.
[L2397] s Random assignment uses chance to assign subjects to the treatments. 
[L2398] Random assignment creates treatment groups that are similar (except for 
[L2399] chance variation) before the treatments are applied. Randomization and 
[L2400] comparison together prevent bias, or systematic favoritism, in experiments.
[L2401] s Applying each treatment to many experimental units (replication)
[L2402] reduces the role of chance variation and makes the experiment more 
[L2403] likely to detect differences in the effects of the treatments.
[L2404] s Many behavioral and medical experiments are double-blind. That is, 
[L2405] neither the subjects nor those interacting with them and measuring their 
[L2406] responses know who is receiving which treatment. If one party knows and 
[L2407] the other doesn’t, then the experiment is single-blind.
[L2408] s Some experiments give a placebo (fake treatment) to a control group. 
[L2409] That helps prevent confounding due to the placebo effect, in which some 
[L2410] patients get better because they expect the treatment to work even though 
[L2411] they have received an inactive treatment.
[L2412] s In addition to comparison, a second form of control is to form blocks of 
[L2413] individuals that are similar in some way that is important to the response. 
[L2414] Randomization is then carried out separately within each block. Blocking 
[L2415] helps reduce unwanted variability among experimental units.
[L2416] s Matched pairs are a common form of blocking for comparing just two 
[L2417] treatments. In some matched pairs designs, each subject receives both 
[L2418] treatments in a random order. In others, the subjects are matched in pairs as 
[L2419] closely as possible, and each subject in a pair receives one of the treatments.

[L3216] Using Studies Wisely
[L3217] Researchers who conduct statistical studies often want to draw conclusions (make 
[L3218] inferences) that go beyond the data they produce. Here are two examples.
[L3219] sThe U.S. Census Bureau carries out a monthly Current Population Survey of 
[L3220] about 60,000 households. Their goal is to use data from these randomly selected 
[L3221] households to estimate the percent of unemployed individuals in the population.
[L3222] sScientists performed an experiment that randomly assigned 21 volunteer sub￾jects to one of two treatments: sleep deprivation for one night or unrestricted 
[L3223] sleep. The experimenters hoped to show that sleep deprivation causes a decrease 
[L3224] in performance two days later.48
[L3225] What type of inference can be made from a particular study? The answer depends 
[L3226] on the design of the study.
[L3227] Scope of Inference
[L3228] In the Census Bureau’s sample survey, the individuals who responded were cho￾sen at random from the population of interest. Random sampling avoids bias and 
[L3229] produces trustworthy estimates of the truth about the population. The Census 
[L3230] Bureau should be safe making an inference about the population based on the 
[L3231] results of the sample.
[L3232] In the sleep deprivation experiment, subjects were randomly assigned to the 
[L3233] sleep deprivation and unrestricted sleep treatments. Random assignment helps 
[L3234] ensure that the two groups of subjects are as similar as possible before the treat￾ments are imposed. If the unrestricted sleep group performs much better than 
[L3235] the sleep deprivation group, and the difference is too large to be explained by 
[L3236] chance variation in the random assignment, it must be due to the treatments. In 
[L3237] that case, the scientists could safely conclude that sleep deprivation caused the 
[L3238] decrease in performance. That is, they can make an inference about cause and 
[L3239] effect. However, since the experiment used volunteer subjects, this limits scien￾tists’ ability to generalize their findings to some larger population of individuals.

[L3245] Let’s recap what we’ve learned about the scope of inference in a statistical study. 
[L3246] Random selection of individuals allows inference about the population. Random 
[L3247] assignment of individuals to groups permits inference about cause and effect. The 
[L3248] chart below summarizes the possibilities.49
[L3249] Were individuals randomly assigned to groups?
[L3250] Yes No
[L3251] Were individuals 
[L3252] randomly selected?
[L3253] Yes
[L3254] Inference about the population: YES Inference about the population: YES
[L3255] Inference about cause and effect: YES Inference about cause and effect: NO
[L3256] No Inference about the population: NO Inference about the population: NO
[L3257] Inference about cause and effect: YES Inference about cause and effect: NO
[L3258] Well-designed experiments randomly assign individuals to treatment groups. 
[L3259] However, most experiments don’t select experimental units at random from the 
[L3260] larger population. That limits such experiments to inference about cause and 
[L3261] effect. Observational studies don’t randomly assign individuals to groups, which 
[L3262] rules out inference about cause and effect. An observational study that uses 
[L3263] random sampling can make an inference about the population. The following 
[L3264] example illustrates all four cases from the table above in a single setting.
[L3265] EXAMPLE Vitamin C and Canker Sores
[L3266] Determining scope of inference
[L3267] A small-town dentist wants to know if a daily dose of 500 milligrams (mg) of vita￾min C will result in fewer canker sores in the mouth than taking no vitamin C.50
[L3268] The dentist is considering the following four study designs.
[L3269] Design 1: Get all dental patients in town with appointments in the next two weeks 
[L3270] to take part in a study. Give each patient a survey with two questions: (1) Do you 
[L3271] take at least 500 mg of vitamin C each day? (2) Do you frequently have canker 
[L3272] sores? Based on patients’ answers to Question 1, divide them into two groups: 
[L3273] those who take at least 500 mg of vitamin C daily and those who don’t.
[L3274] Design 2: Get all dental patients in town with appointments in the next two weeks 
[L3275] to take part in a study. Randomly assign half of them to take 500 mg of vitamin 
[L3276] C each day and the other half to abstain from taking vitamin C for three months.
[L3277] Design 3: Select a random sample of dental patients in town and get them to take 
[L3278] part in a study. Divide the patients into two groups as in Design 1.
[L3279] Design 4: Select a random sample of dental patients in town and get them to take 
[L3280] part in a study. Randomly assign half of them to take 500 mg of vitamin C each 
[L3281] day and the other half to abstain from taking vitamin C for three months.

[L3288] Design 1: Since the patients were not randomly selected, the dentist cannot infer that this result

[L3316] The Challenges of 
[L3317] Establishing Causation
[L3318] A well-designed experiment tells us that changes in the explanatory variable cause 
[L3319] changes in the response variable. More precisely, it tells us that this happened 
[L3320] for specific individuals in the specific environment of this specific experiment. 
[L3321] The serious threat is that the treatments, the subjects, or the environment of our 
[L3322] experiment may not be realistic. Lack of realism can limit our ability to apply the 
[L3323] conclusions of an experiment to the settings of greatest interest.
[L3324] Do Center Brake Lights Reduce Rear-End Crashes?
[L3325] Lack of realism
[L3326] Do those high center brake lights, required on all cars sold in the United States 
[L3327] since 1986, really reduce rear-end collisions? Randomized comparative experi￾ments with fleets of rental and business cars, done before the lights were required, 
[L3328] showed that the third brake light reduced rear-end collisions by as much as 50%. 
[L3329] But requiring the third light in all cars led to only a 5% drop.
[L3330] What happened? Most cars did not have the extra brake light when the experi￾ments were carried out, so it caught the eye of following drivers. Now that almost 
[L3331] all cars have the third light, they no longer capture attention.

[L3337] In some cases, it isn’t practical or even ethical to do an experiment. Consider 
[L3338] these important questions:
[L3339] sDoes texting while driving increase the risk of having an accident?
[L3340] sDoes going to church regularly help people live longer?
[L3341] sDoes smoking cause lung cancer?
[L3342] To answer these cause-and-effect questions, we just need to perform a randomized 
[L3343] comparative experiment. Unfortunately, we can’t randomly assign people to text 
[L3344] while driving or to attend church or to smoke cigarettes. The best data we have 
[L3345] about these and many other cause-and-effect questions come from observational 
[L3346] studies.
[L3347] It is sometimes possible to build a strong case for causation in the absence of 
[L3348] experiments. The evidence that smoking causes lung cancer is about as strong as 
[L3349] nonexperimental evidence can be.
[L3350] Does Smoking Cause Lung Cancer?
[L3351] Living with observational studies
[L3352] Doctors had long observed that most lung cancer patients were smokers. 
[L3353] Comparison of smokers and similar nonsmokers showed a very strong asso￾ciation between smoking and death from lung cancer. Could the association 
[L3354] be due to a lurking variable? Is there some genetic factor that makes people 
[L3355] both more likely to get addicted to nicotine and to develop lung cancer? If 
[L3356] so, then smoking and lung cancer would be strongly associated even if 
[L3357] smoking had no direct effect on the lungs. Or maybe confounding is to 
[L3358] blame. It might be that smokers live unhealthy lives in other ways (diet, 
[L3359] alcohol, lack of exercise) and that some other habit confounded with smok￾ing is a cause of lung cancer. How were these objections overcome?

[L3390] Medical professionals are taught to follow the basic principle “First, do no harm.” 
[L3391] Shouldn’t those who carry out statistical studies follow the same principle? Most 
[L3392] reasonable people think so. But this may not always be as simple as it sounds. De￾cide whether you think each of the following studies is ethical or unethical.

[L3396] sAre companies discriminating against some individuals in the hiring process?

[L3398] applicants, with the only difference being the gender of the applicant. They 
[L3399] send the fake résumés to companies advertising positions and keep track of the 
[L3400] number of males and females who are contacted for interviews.
[L3401] sIn a medical study of a new drug for migraine sufferers, volunteer subjects are 
[L3402] randomly assigned to two groups. Members of the first group are given a placebo

[L3404] knows whether they are taking a placebo or the active drug. Neither do any of

[L3406] sWill people try to stop someone from driving drunk? A television news pro￾gram hires an actor to play a drunk driver and uses a hidden camera to record the 
[L3407] behavior of individuals who encounter the driver.
[L3408] The most complex issues of data ethics arise when we collect data from people. 
[L3409] The ethical difficulties are more severe for experiments that impose some treatment 
[L3410] on people than for sample surveys that simply gather information. Trials of new 
[L3411] medical treatments, for example, can do harm as well as good to their subjects. Here 
[L3412] are some basic standards of data ethics that must be obeyed by all studies that gather 
[L3413] data from human subjects, both observational studies and experiments.
[L3414] Basic Data Ethics
[L3415] All planned studies must be reviewed in advance by an institutional review 
[L3416] board charged with protecting the safety and well-being of the subjects.
[L3417] All individuals who are subjects in a study must give their informed consent
[L3418] before data are collected.
[L3419] All individual data must be kept confidential. Only statistical summaries for 
[L3420] groups of subjects may be made public.

[L3432] are informed about the nature of the study and about any potential risks. Once

[L3446] obtained consent from its participants, and has actually
