```latex
\documentclass[11pt]{article}

\usepackage[margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{amsmath,amssymb,amsthm}
\usepackage{enumitem}
\usepackage{booktabs}
\usepackage{hyperref}

% --- lecture-notes style environments ---
\theoremstyle{definition}
\newtheorem{definition}{Definition}[section]
\newtheorem{example}{Example}[section]
\newtheorem{remark}{Remark}[section]

\newcommand{\PP}{\mathbb{P}}

\title{Lecture Notes: Using Studies Wisely (Section 4.3)}
\author{}
\date{}

\begin{document}
\maketitle
\tableofcontents

\section{Why ``using studies wisely'' matters}
Many statistical studies aim to make conclusions that go \emph{beyond} the individuals actually studied.
This section is about \emph{what you are entitled to conclude} given the design:
\begin{itemize}
\item Can we generalize to a population?
\item Can we claim cause-and-effect?
\item Are there limits from realism and ethics?
\end{itemize}

\section{Scope of inference}

\begin{definition}[Inference (informal)]
\emph{Inference} means drawing conclusions that go beyond the observed sample/subjects.
The \emph{scope of inference} is the set of claims that are justified by the study design.
\end{definition}

\subsection{Two key design features}
There are two different ``superpowers'' we might want:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \textbf{Inference about a population:} justified by \emph{random selection} (random sampling).
\item \textbf{Inference about cause-and-effect:} justified by \emph{random assignment} (in an experiment).
\end{enumerate}

\begin{remark}[Do not mix these up]
Random \emph{sampling} supports generalization to a population.
Random \emph{assignment} supports a causal claim \emph{in the study setting}.
A study can have one, both, or neither.
\end{remark}

\subsection{The scope-of-inference table}
Let:
\[
\text{RS}=\text{random selection from a population},\qquad
\text{RA}=\text{random assignment to treatments/groups}.
\]
Then:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{@{}lll@{}}
\toprule
 & \textbf{RA: Yes} & \textbf{RA: No} \\
\midrule
\textbf{RS: Yes} &
Population inference: YES \quad Causation: YES &
Population inference: YES \quad Causation: NO \\
\textbf{RS: No} &
Population inference: NO \quad Causation: YES &
Population inference: NO \quad Causation: NO \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\begin{remark}[Typical real-world pattern]
Many experiments use volunteers (RA yes, RS no). They can support causation,
but generalizing to a broader population requires extra justification.
\end{remark}

\subsection{A basic effect-size computation (often used in this chapter)}
When the response is binary (e.g.\ ``has canker sores: yes/no''), we often compare
\emph{proportions} across groups:
\[
\hat p_1=\frac{x_1}{n_1},\qquad \hat p_2=\frac{x_2}{n_2},\qquad
\widehat{\Delta}_p=\hat p_1-\hat p_2.
\]
Here $\widehat{\Delta}_p$ estimates the treatment effect in a two-group setting.
Whether this \emph{difference} supports causation or generalization depends on RS/RA.

\section{Worked example: four designs for the same question}

\begin{example}[Vitamin C and canker sores: four designs]
A dentist wants to know whether taking 500 mg of vitamin C daily reduces canker sores
among dental patients in a town. Consider four designs:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\textbf{Design \arabic*:}, leftmargin=*]
\item \textbf{Convenience + observational (no RS, no RA).}
Recruit patients with appointments in the next two weeks. Ask who already takes vitamin C.
Compare the proportion with sores among users vs nonusers.

\item \textbf{Convenience + experiment (no RS, yes RA).}
Recruit patients with appointments in the next two weeks, then randomly assign half to vitamin C
and half to no vitamin C (or placebo). Compare proportions.

\item \textbf{Random sample + observational (yes RS, no RA).}
Take a random sample of dental patients in town. Ask who already takes vitamin C.
Compare proportions among users vs nonusers.

\item \textbf{Random sample + experiment (yes RS, yes RA).}
Take a random sample of dental patients in town, then randomly assign half to vitamin C
and half to no vitamin C (or placebo). Compare proportions.
\end{enumerate}

To make this concrete, suppose in a particular comparison we get:
\[
\text{Vitamin C group: } n_1=40,\ x_1=8 \text{ have sores } \Rightarrow \hat p_1=\frac{8}{40}=0.20,
\]
\[
\text{No vitamin C group: } n_2=40,\ x_2=18 \text{ have sores } \Rightarrow \hat p_2=\frac{18}{40}=0.45,
\]
so
\[
\widehat{\Delta}_p=\hat p_1-\hat p_2=0.20-0.45=-0.25.
\]
A negative difference suggests fewer sores in the vitamin C group.

\medskip
\noindent\textbf{What may we conclude?}
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Design 1:} no population inference (no RS) and no causation (no RA).
You can only describe an association in those recruited patients.
\item \textbf{Design 2:} no population inference (no RS), but causation is supported (RA),
\emph{for the recruited subjects in this setting} (assuming good control and compliance).
\item \textbf{Design 3:} population inference is supported (RS), but causation is not (no RA).
You can generalize the observed association to the town's dental-patient population,
but confounding is possible.
\item \textbf{Design 4:} both population inference and causation are supported (RS + RA),
\emph{for the population that was actually sampled} (here: the town's dental patients).
\end{itemize}
\end{example}

\begin{remark}[A common pitfall: wrong population]
Even in Design 4, if the sample was drawn from \emph{dental patients}, you cannot automatically
extend the conclusion to \emph{all town residents}. The population is determined by the sampling frame.
\end{remark}

\section{The challenges of establishing causation}

\subsection{Internal validity vs realism}
A well-designed experiment (with RA and proper control) supports causation \emph{in the study setting}.
However, applying the result elsewhere can fail due to \emph{lack of realism}:
the subjects, environment, or implementation may differ from the situation you care about.

\begin{example}[Brake lights: context changes can shrink effects]
Suppose early fleet experiments suggested an intervention reduced rear-end collisions by 50\%.
If a fleet had 100 rear-end collisions/year, a 50\% drop predicts about 50/year.
But if the intervention later becomes universal and the observed reduction is only 5\%,
the prediction becomes 95/year instead.
Same causal mechanism idea, very different context---hence very different effect size.
\end{example}

\subsection{When experiments are impossible}
Some important causal questions cannot be tested by random assignment
because it is impractical or unethical (e.g.\ forcing harmful exposures).
In such cases, observational studies may be the best available evidence.

\subsection{Arguing causation from observational evidence (a checklist)}
When experiments cannot be done, strong causal arguments typically rely on multiple lines of evidence.

\begin{definition}[Nonexperimental evidence checklist for causation]
A causal claim from observational evidence is strengthened when:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \textbf{Association is strong} (large effect size).
\item \textbf{Association is consistent} across studies and populations.
\item \textbf{Dose--response} appears (more exposure $\Rightarrow$ stronger response; reduced exposure $\Rightarrow$ reduced risk).
\item \textbf{Correct time order} holds (cause precedes effect, often with a plausible lag).
\item \textbf{Plausible mechanism} exists (biological/physical explanation, often supported by lab/animal studies).
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{example}[``Strong association'' with risk ratios (toy numbers)]
In a cohort study:
\[
\text{Smokers: } n=10{,}000,\ \text{lung cancer }=200 \Rightarrow \hat p_S=0.020,
\]
\[
\text{Nonsmokers: } n=10{,}000,\ \text{lung cancer }=10 \Rightarrow \hat p_N=0.001.
\]
Risk ratio (RR) estimate:
\[
\widehat{\mathrm{RR}}=\frac{\hat p_S}{\hat p_N}=\frac{0.020}{0.001}=20.
\]
A ratio near 20 is a strong association. By itself it does not prove causation, but it is one component
of a broader causal argument using the checklist above.
\end{example}

\section{Data ethics (human subjects)}

\subsection{Basic standards}
Studies involving humans must follow core ethical requirements.

\begin{definition}[Basic data ethics requirements]
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \textbf{Institutional Review Board (IRB) review:} the study plan must be reviewed in advance.
\item \textbf{Informed consent:} participants must agree, after being informed about what will happen and risks.
\item \textbf{Confidentiality:} individual data must be protected; only group summaries should be made public.
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}[Purpose of an IRB]
An IRB is primarily about protecting participants' rights and welfare.
It can require design changes, reviews consent procedures, and monitors ongoing work.
\end{remark}

\subsection{Confidentiality vs anonymity}
\begin{definition}[Confidentiality vs anonymity]
\textbf{Confidentiality} means the researchers may know identities, but must protect them
(e.g.\ separate identifiers from data, restrict access, report only aggregates).

\textbf{Anonymity} means identities are not known even to the study organizers.
True anonymity is uncommon and can prevent follow-up with participants.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}[Modern risk: re-identification]
Even if direct identifiers are removed, combining multiple data sources can sometimes re-identify individuals.
This is why privacy practice must consider the broader data environment.
\end{remark}

\begin{example}[Simple confidentiality plan]
A survey assigns each participant an ID number. Names and contact details are stored in a separate file
from responses. Analyses and reports use only the ID and publish only group summaries (means/proportions).
\end{example}

\section*{Exercises (curated from Section 4.3)}
\addcontentsline{toc}{section}{Exercises (curated from Section 4.3)}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\textbf{4.3.\arabic*}, leftmargin=*]

\item \textbf{Random sampling vs random assignment.}
Explain the difference between what random sampling allows you to infer and what random assignment allows you to infer.

\item \textbf{Classify designs using the scope-of-inference table.}
For each design below, state whether population inference is justified and whether a causal claim is justified.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Volunteers are randomly assigned to Treatment A or B.
\item A random sample is taken from a population and subjects are only observed (no imposed treatment).
\item A convenience sample is taken and subjects choose whether to take a supplement; outcomes are compared.
\item A random sample is taken and then subjects are randomly assigned to treatment or placebo.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Foster care vs orphanages (design and conclusion).}
A study on 136 abandoned children in one city randomly assigns half to foster care and half to remain in orphanages.
What conclusion(s) are justified? Comment on both causation and generalization.

\item \textbf{Frozen batteries (design and conclusion).}
A manufacturer takes a random sample of 100 AA batteries from its warehouse and randomly assigns
50 to freezer storage and 50 to room temperature for 3 years. At the end, freezer batteries have significantly higher charge.
What conclusion(s) are justified? Be precise about the population (if any).

\item \textbf{Words per day: women vs men (what can and cannot be concluded).}
Researchers record daily word counts for volunteers and find women average 16{,}215 and men 15{,}669,
with the difference not statistically significant. What can be concluded? What can \emph{not} be concluded?

\item \textbf{Attend church, live longer?}
A study uses a random sample of adults, measures attendance at religious services and later mortality.
Even after adjusting for some health behaviors, non-attenders are reported as about 25\% more likely to have died.
What is the proper conclusion and why?

\item \textbf{Driving simulator and daytime running lights (realism).}
A driving-simulator experiment suggests daytime running lights reduce accidents.
Give at least two concerns about generalizing this result to real-world driving.

\item \textbf{Frustration study in a lab (realism).}
A psychologist studies teamwork under frustration using students in a lab game rigged to induce failure.
Can the result be generalized to long-term workplace teams facing months of project setbacks? Explain.

\item \textbf{Causation without experiments.}
State the five-item checklist for supporting causation from observational studies. Then, in one paragraph,
explain how \emph{two} of the items reduce concerns about lurking variables/confounding.

\item \textbf{Confidentiality vs anonymity.}
Define confidentiality and anonymity. Give one simple example of each (or explain why true anonymity is hard).

\item \textbf{Ethics judgments (brief).}
For each study idea, list one key ethical issue and say whether it seems ethically acceptable \emph{in principle} under proper oversight:
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Testing a new cancer drug on animals before human trials.
\item Sending equivalent fictitious resumes to employers to study discrimination.
\item A double-blind, placebo-controlled migraine drug trial with volunteer subjects.
\item Filming public reactions to a staged ``drunk driver'' using a hidden camera.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Minimal risk (concept).}
Consider three procedures: (i) finger prick for a drop of blood, (ii) drawing blood from the arm for full tests,
(iii) inserting a tube that remains in the arm for repeated blood draws. Rank these from lowest to highest risk and justify briefly.

\end{enumerate}

\end{document}
```

```latex
\item Both: YES for the warehouse population of AA batteries at the time of sampling (RS + RA), assuming the sample was genuinely random and the experiment properly controlled. Generalization beyond that warehouse/time requires extra justification.

\item You can say: in this volunteer sample, there is no convincing statistical evidence of a sex difference in mean word count (given the analysis used).

\item Observational with RS: you may generalize an association to the sampled adult population, but you cannot claim church attendance \emph{causes} longer life; residual confounding and measurement issues may remain.

\item Generalizing is doubtful: lab task, time scale, stakes, incentives, and social dynamics differ greatly; ``failure'' is artificial; subjects are students; external validity (realism) is weak.

\item Checklist: strong association; consistent across studies/populations; dose--response; cause precedes effect; plausible mechanism.
Consistency reduces the chance that one specific lurking variable explains all findings; dose--response makes it harder for a single fixed confounder to mimic the pattern (and reversal after stopping exposure strengthens the causal story).
```

Below are **three end-to-end case studies** designed so that **each one** meaningfully hits concepts from:

- **4.1 Sampling & Surveys** (population vs sample, Simple Random Sample (SRS), stratified/cluster sampling, undercoverage, nonresponse, response bias, wording effects; “big \(n\)” not fixing bias)
- **4.2 Experiments** (treatments, factors/levels, random assignment, control/placebo, blinding, replication, blocking, matched pairs; effect sizes via differences in means/proportions)
- **4.3 Using Studies Wisely** (scope of inference: random selection vs random assignment; realism/external validity; arguing causation without experiments; human-subject ethics—Institutional Review Board (IRB), informed consent, confidentiality)

I’m writing these as **specs you can hand to Codex CLI** later: theme, scope, and a concrete synthetic-data blueprint (variables + generative model + built-in “gotchas”).

---

## Case Study 1 — Education: “Digital Curfew” intervention and student outcomes

### Theme / real-world story
A school network wants to know:
1) **How much sleep do students actually get?** (survey problem)
2) **Does a “digital curfew” app increase sleep and improve exam performance?** (experiment problem)
3) **Can we generalize results to all students in the network?** (scope-of-inference problem)

### What it illustrates
- **4.1:** convenience sample bias (early arrivals / library intercept), voluntary response bias, nonresponse correlated with outcomes, stratified sampling by school/grade, measurement error in self-reports
- **4.2:** cluster randomization (by class), blocking (by school), noncompliance, treatment effect estimation
- **4.3:** RA (random assignment) yes but RS (random selection) often no → causal claim for participants but limited population generalization; ethics with minors

### Synthetic data generation plan (population-first)
**Create a finite population** of students across multiple schools; then “run” multiple study designs as samples drawn from that population.

**Population structure**
- Schools: \(S=8\)
- Classes per school: \(C=6\)
- Students per class: \(m=25\)
- Total \(N = 8\cdot 6\cdot 25 = 1200\) (small enough to compute exactly; can scale up later)

**Latent and observed variables**
- Socioeconomic status (SES): categorical \(\{0,1,2\}\) with school-specific mix  
- Baseline ability \(A \sim \mathcal N(0,1)\)
- “Conscientiousness” latent \(H \sim \mathcal N(0,1)\) (drives both outcomes and survey participation)
- Screen time (hours/day):  
  \[
  \text{screen} = \max\{0,\ 3.5 + 0.8\cdot \mathbf{1}(\text{SES}=2) - 0.5H + \epsilon_s\},\quad \epsilon_s\sim\mathcal N(0,1)
  \]
- True sleep (hours/night):  
  \[
  \text{sleep}_{\text{true}} = \mathrm{clip}\big(8.0 - 0.35\cdot \text{screen} + 0.25H + \epsilon_\ell,\ 4,\ 10\big)
  \]
- Exam score (0–100):  
  \[
  \text{score} = \mathrm{clip}\big(65 + 10A + 2.0(\text{sleep}_{\text{true}}-7) + 1.5\cdot \text{SES} + \epsilon_y,\ 0,\ 100\big)
  \]
- Self-reported sleep (survey measurement error + desirability bias):  
  \[
  \text{sleep}_{\text{self}} = \text{sleep}_{\text{true}} + \eta,\quad \eta\sim\mathcal N(\mu_\eta, \sigma_\eta^2)
  \]
  where set \(\mu_\eta>0\) for high-SES (over-reporting) to model response bias.

**Survey participation mechanisms (to create nonresponse bias)**
- Response probability:
  \[
  \Pr(\text{respond}=1) = \mathrm{logistic}(-0.5 + 0.6H - 0.4\cdot \mathbf{1}(\text{sleep}_{\text{true}}<6))
  \]
So lower-sleep students respond less → nonresponse bias.

### Study designs “run” on the population
**Part A (4.1): compare sampling methods**
1) **Convenience sample**: first 200 students arriving before 7:15am  
   - Model: those arriving early have lower sleep by construction (they must wake earlier)
2) **Voluntary response online poll**: anyone can click; heavy selection on strong opinions (model: respond probability increases with extreme screen time or extreme fatigue)
3) **Stratified random sample**: sample within each school proportional to size; compare estimates to the known population mean

**Key calculations**
- Estimate population mean sleep via \(\bar x\); show bias: \(\bar x_{\text{conv}} - \mu_{\text{pop}}\)
- Show “big \(n\)” fallacy: voluntary response can have huge \(n\) but still biased
- Quantify nonresponse rate and resulting distortion (compare respondents vs nonrespondents)

**Part B (4.2): experiment**
- Intervention: “digital curfew app” deployed at class level  
- **Random assignment**: randomly assign classes within each school to Treatment vs Control (**blocked by school**)  
- Compliance: only a fraction comply; compliance probability increases with \(H\) (realistic—and creates treatment effect dilution)
- Treatment effect mechanism:
  - For compliers: screen time decreases by about 1.0 hour/day on average
  - Sleep increases via the sleep equation above
  - Score increases via sleep-to-score link

**Analyses**
- Difference in mean sleep and mean score between groups
- Intention-to-treat (compare by assigned group) vs per-protocol (compare by compliance; discuss bias risk)

**Part C (4.3): scope + ethics**
- If the experiment used only volunteer classes → RA yes, RS no ⇒ causal inferences mainly for those participants
- If schools were randomly sampled from a district list and then classes randomized → RS+RA ⇒ stronger population + causal inference
- Ethics: minors ⇒ parent/guardian consent, privacy, minimal risk framing

## Case Study 2 — Health: supplement observational “breakthrough” vs randomized trial (Simpson’s paradox baked in)

### Theme / real-world story
A supplement company claims its product lowers systolic blood pressure (SBP). You will:
1) Replicate the claim with an **observational study** (and show it can be misleading)
2) Run a **randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trial**
3) Interpret what can be concluded and what cannot (especially about population generalization)

### What it illustrates
- **4.1:** sampling frame (clinic patients vs general population), self-selection, nonresponse/dropout, response bias on lifestyle variables
- **4.2:** placebo effect, blinding, random assignment, matched pairs crossover option, replication, blocking by baseline SBP
- **4.3:** causal inference vs generalization; arguing causation without experiments; ethics (IRB, informed consent, confidentiality)

### Synthetic data generation plan (build confounding + Simpson’s paradox)
**Population**
- \(N=20{,}000\) adults in a city
- Covariates:
  - age 30–75
  - latent health-consciousness \(H\)
  - exercise minutes/week
  - baseline SBP

**Core structural model**
- \(H \sim \mathcal N(0,1)\)  
- Exercise:
  \[
  \text{ex} = \mathrm{clip}(120 + 60H + \epsilon,\ 0,\ 600)
  \]
- Baseline SBP:
  \[
  \text{SBP}_0 = 125 + 0.6(\text{age}-50) - 4H + \epsilon_0
  \]
- **Supplement uptake (self-selection)**:
  \[
  \Pr(\text{supp}=1)=\mathrm{logistic}(-1 + 1.2H + 0.02(\text{age}-50))
  \]
So supplement users are more health-conscious and differ in baseline risk.

**True causal effect**
- True supplement effect: \(-2\) mmHg (small)
- Placebo effect: \(-1\) mmHg if people believe they’re treated
- Measurement noise: \(\pm 3\) mmHg

**Observed follow-up SBP (observational world)**
- If observational (no random assignment), follow-up SBP depends on exercise change too:
  \[
  \text{SBP}_1 = \text{SBP}_0 - 0.01(\text{ex}-120) + \tau\cdot \mathbf{1}(\text{supp}=1) + \epsilon_1
  \]
with \(\tau=-2\). Because \(\text{supp}\) is correlated with \(H\) and exercise, naive comparisons overstate the supplement effect.

**Simpson’s paradox knob**
- Introduce a risk stratum \(R\in\{\text{high},\text{low}\}\) determined by age and baseline SBP.
- Make supplement adoption very high in low-risk and low in high-risk (or vice versa) so aggregated results reverse stratified results.

### Study designs
**Part A (observational “study”)**
- Clinic recruits “anyone who already takes supplement” + “anyone who doesn’t”
- Compare \(\bar{\text{SBP}}_1\) between groups → often shows huge effect due to confounding
- Show stratifying by risk group reverses or shrinks the effect (Simpson’s paradox demonstration)

**Part B (randomized trial)**
- Recruit volunteers (or random sample from clinic patient list—two variants)
- **Random assignment** to supplement vs placebo
- **Double-blind**: neither subjects nor assessors know assignment
- Dropout probability depends on side effects and on baseline SBP (introduces missingness)

**Optional extension (matched pairs / crossover)**
- For short-lived biomarkers: each subject gets placebo and supplement on different weeks in random order; analyze within-subject differences

### Key calculations
- Difference in means: \(\widehat{\Delta} = \bar y_{\text{supp}} - \bar y_{\text{control}}\)
- Difference in proportions if using binary outcomes (e.g., “SBP controlled < 130”)
- For matched pairs: \(d_i = y_i(\text{supp}) - y_i(\text{placebo})\), analyze \(\bar d\)
- Interpret “statistically significant” vs “clinically meaningful” (e.g., 2 mmHg might matter at population scale, but for individuals it’s modest)

### 4.3 interpretation hooks
- Volunteers + random assignment ⇒ causation supported, generalization limited
- Random sampling + random assignment ⇒ stronger population + causation
- Observational: use causation checklist (strength, consistency, dose-response, time order, mechanism) and show where it fails or is ambiguous
- Ethics: IRB review, informed consent, confidentiality; also discuss placebo ethics (acceptable when no proven standard treatment is withheld)

---

## Case Study 3 — Public policy / environment: road-safety intervention with external-validity trap

### Theme / real-world story
A city considers installing a new school-zone warning system (signage + flashing beacons). You will:
1) Start with a **before-after** analysis that looks impressive but is misleading
2) Design a **cluster randomized field experiment** across intersections (blocking by traffic volume)
3) Discuss why simulator/lab results may not transfer to real roads (realism)

### What it illustrates
- **4.1:** sampling frame (which intersections?), cluster sampling (by neighborhoods), undercoverage (missing near-miss events if only police reports), measurement bias
- **4.2:** randomized comparative experiment at cluster level, blocking, replication, control group, factorial option (signage vs signage+beacon)
- **4.3:** realism/external validity; causal inference limits when experiments can’t be done; ethics/privacy if using video

### Synthetic data generation plan (counts + regression-to-mean built in)
**Population**
- \(N=200\) intersections
- Covariates:
  - traffic volume \(V\) (vehicles/day)
  - school zone indicator \(Z\in\{0,1\}\)
  - baseline safety infrastructure \(B\in\{0,1\}\)

**Baseline accident rate (monthly)**
Use Poisson counts with intersection random effects:
\[
\lambda_{i,0} = \exp(\alpha + \beta_V \log V_i + \beta_Z Z_i + \beta_B B_i + u_i)
\]
where \(u_i\sim \mathcal N(0,\sigma^2)\). Then:
\[
Y_{i,t} \sim \mathrm{Poisson}(\lambda_{i,t})
\]

**Treatment effect**
- Two-level treatment:
  - \(T=0\): no change
  - \(T=1\): signage+beacon
- Effect heterogeneity:
  - If \(B=0\): 12% reduction \(\Rightarrow \lambda \times 0.88\)
  - If \(B=1\): 3% reduction \(\Rightarrow \lambda \times 0.97\)
- Effect decay (novelty wears off):
  \[
  \text{multiplier}(t)=1 - 0.12\cdot e^{-t/6}\quad \text{(example)}
  \]

**Regression-to-mean trap**
Select “treatment” intersections as those with the worst recent accident counts. Even without any true improvement, their next period often looks better.

### Study designs
**Part A (bad but common): “treat the worst 20 intersections, compare before vs after”**
- Shows large improvement largely due to regression to mean + seasonality
- No control group ⇒ cannot attribute to intervention

**Part B (better): randomized field trial**
- Choose a set of eligible intersections (define frame clearly)
- Block by \((Z, \text{volume quartile})\)
- Randomly assign within blocks to:
  - control
  - signage+beacon
- Optionally factorial:
  - signage only
  - beacon only
  - both
  - neither

**Part C (realism): simulator vs field**
- Generate a separate “simulator dataset” where effect size is much larger (drivers pay more attention in artificial setting), then show field effect smaller. This makes the external validity point concrete.

### Key calculations
- Accident rates per month; rate ratios \(\widehat{\mathrm{RR}} = \bar Y_T/\bar Y_C\)
- Difference-in-differences:
  \[
  (\bar Y_{T,\text{after}} - \bar Y_{T,\text{before}}) - (\bar Y_{C,\text{after}} - \bar Y_{C,\text{before}})
  \]
- Show how conclusions change across designs (before-after vs randomized)

### Ethics / privacy notes
- If using video/plate data: confidentiality and minimization are real issues even if “public”
- If intervention is city-wide infrastructure: generally minimal risk, but transparency and data governance matter

---

## Common implementation pattern (so all 3 feel unified)
For each case study, generate:
1) **population.csv** (the full finite population with “true” outcomes and latent confounders)
2) **survey\_samples/** (convenience, voluntary response, SRS/stratified/cluster)
3) **experiment\_data/** (assignment, compliance, outcomes, missingness/dropout)
4) **analysis notebooks/scripts** that compute:
   - true population parameters
   - sample estimates + bias
   - treatment effect estimates (difference in means/proportions; paired differences where relevant)
   - scope-of-inference classification (RS/RA matrix) + interpretation text

```latex
\documentclass[11pt]{article}

\usepackage[margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{amsmath,amssymb}
\usepackage{booktabs}
\usepackage{enumitem}
\usepackage{hyperref}

% Toggle solutions on/off:
\newif\ifsolutions

\title{Case Study 1 (Sampling, Experiments, Scope of Inference): Digital Curfew in Schools}
\author{}
\date{}

\begin{document}
\maketitle

\section*{Context (read carefully)}
A school network is considering a \emph{digital curfew} policy: a phone app that blocks social media and games from 10:30pm to 6:00am on school nights. The network wants three things:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item A trustworthy estimate of \textbf{average sleep} among students (survey design).
\item Evidence on whether the app \textbf{causes} more sleep and better academic performance (experimental design).
\item Clear statements of \textbf{what conclusions are justified} by each design choice (scope of inference).
\end{enumerate}

All data in this handout are \textbf{synthetic but realistic}. You must show working and interpret results in plain language.

\section{Part I: Sampling and Surveys (Section 4.1 concepts)}
\subsection{Population and ``ground truth'' (administrative device data)}
The school network has anonymized device-based sleep estimates for the full population, summarized by stratum (School $\times$ Grade). Treat the following as the \textbf{population truth}.

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{cccc}
\toprule
Stratum & Population size $N_h$ & Device mean sleep (hours) $\mu_{h}$ \\
\midrule
A10 & 180 & 6.9 \\
A11 & 150 & 6.4 \\
B10 & 220 & 7.3 \\
B11 & 200 & 6.8 \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\textbf{1.\arabic*}, leftmargin=*]
\item Compute the overall population mean sleep (device-based) across all students:
\[
\mu_{\text{pop}}=\frac{\sum_h N_h \mu_h}{\sum_h N_h}.
\]
Give your answer to 3 decimal places.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Convenience sample: early arrivals}
A staff member surveys the \emph{first 20 students to arrive before 7:15am}, asking for self-reported sleep last night (hours):

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{cccccccccc}
\toprule
ID & EA01 & EA02 & EA03 & EA04 & EA05 & EA06 & EA07 & EA08 & EA09 \\
Sleep & 5.2 & 5.5 & 5.8 & 6.0 & 6.1 & 6.2 & 6.3 & 5.9 & 6.4 \\
\midrule
ID & EA10 & EA11 & EA12 & EA13 & EA14 & EA15 & EA16 & EA17 & EA18 \\
Sleep & 6.0 & 6.1 & 5.7 & 6.5 & 6.2 & 6.0 & 6.3 & 5.6 & 6.4 \\
\midrule
ID & EA19 & EA20 \\
Sleep & 6.1 & 5.8 \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\textbf{2.\arabic*}, leftmargin=*]
\item Compute the convenience-sample mean $\bar x_{\text{conv}}$.
\item Compute the \textbf{bias relative to the population truth}:
\[
\text{Bias} = \bar x_{\text{conv}}-\mu_{\text{pop}}.
\]
State the direction (overestimate/underestimate) and explain in one sentence \emph{why} this sampling method tends to bias sleep.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Voluntary response online poll}
An online ``sleep check-in'' is posted on the student portal; participation is optional. 1200 students respond. Their responses (rounded to whole hours) are:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
\toprule
Sleep hours & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 & 9 & 10 \\
Count & 20 & 60 & 150 & 300 & 380 & 220 & 70 \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\textbf{3.\arabic*}, leftmargin=*]
\item Compute the voluntary-response mean:
\[
\bar x_{\text{vol}}=\frac{\sum_h (\text{hours})\cdot(\text{count})}{1200}.
\]
\item Compute bias relative to $\mu_{\text{pop}}$.
\item Give \textbf{two concrete reasons} this can be badly biased even though $n=1200$ is large.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Stratified random sample (SRS within strata)}
A statistician uses stratified random sampling by School $\times$ Grade and gets the following sample summaries:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
\toprule
Stratum & $n_h$ & $\sum$ self-sleep & $\sum$ device-sleep \\
\midrule
A10 & 18 & 129.6 & 124.2 \\
A11 & 15 & 103.5 & 96.0 \\
B10 & 22 & 165.0 & 160.6 \\
B11 & 20 & 138.0 & 136.0 \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\textbf{4.\arabic*}, leftmargin=*]
\item Compute each stratum sample mean for self-report and device:
\[
\bar x^{(\text{self})}_h=\frac{\sum \text{self}}{n_h},\qquad
\bar x^{(\text{dev})}_h=\frac{\sum \text{device}}{n_h}.
\]
\item Compute the \textbf{stratified estimate} of mean self-reported sleep:
\[
\hat\mu_{\text{self, strat}}=\sum_h \frac{N_h}{N}\bar x^{(\text{self})}_h,
\quad N=\sum_h N_h.
\]
\item Compute the analogous stratified estimate using device sleep, $\hat\mu_{\text{dev, strat}}$, and compare it to $\mu_{\text{pop}}$.
\item For each stratum compute the \textbf{measurement bias} (self minus device): $\bar x^{(\text{self})}_h-\bar x^{(\text{dev})}_h$.
Interpret: which stratum seems to over-report most?
\end{enumerate}
```

```python
import pandas as pd

CONTAMINATION_PC = 0.06  # control-group adoption rate assumed in the handout (optional challenge)

def wmean(x, w):
    return (x * w).sum() / w.sum()

def main():
    pop = pd.read_csv("data/handout/population_strata.csv")
    N_total = pop["N"].sum()
    mu_pop = (pop["N"] * pop["mean_device_sleep"]).sum() / N_total

    early = pd.read_csv("data/handout/survey_early_arrivals.csv")
    conv_mean = early["sleep_self_hours"].mean()
    conv_bias = conv_mean - mu_pop

    vol = pd.read_csv("data/handout/survey_voluntary_counts.csv")
    vol_mean = (vol["sleep_hours"] * vol["count"]).sum() / vol["count"].sum()
    vol_bias = vol_mean - mu_pop

    strat = pd.read_csv("data/handout/survey_stratified_sample_summary.csv")
    strat = strat.merge(pop[["stratum", "N"]], on="stratum", how="left")
    strat["mean_self"] = strat["sum_sleep_self"] / strat["n"]
    strat["mean_dev"] = strat["sum_sleep_device"] / strat["n"]
    mu_self_strat = (strat["N"] * strat["mean_self"]).sum() / N_total
    mu_dev_strat = (strat["N"] * strat["mean_dev"]).sum() / N_total

    nonr = pd.read_csv("data/handout/survey_nonresponse.csv")
    nonr = nonr.merge(pop[["stratum", "N"]], on="stratum", how="left")
    nonr["resp_rate"] = nonr["n_responded"] / nonr["n_selected"]
    overall_resp_rate = nonr["n_responded"].sum() / nonr["n_selected"].sum()
    mu_post = (nonr["N"] * nonr["respondent_mean_self_sleep"]).sum() / N_total

    wording = pd.read_csv("data/handout/survey_wording_effect.csv")
    neutral = float(wording.loc[wording["question_version"] == "Neutral", "mean_self_sleep"].iloc[0])
    leading = float(wording.loc[wording["question_version"] == "Leading", "mean_self_sleep"].iloc[0])
    wording_diff = leading - neutral

    exp = pd.read_csv("data/handout/experiment_class_summary.csv")
    T = exp[exp["group"] == "T"].copy()
    C = exp[exp["group"] == "C"].copy()

    # ITT on follow-up
    sleep1_T = wmean(T["sleep_followup"], T["n"])
    sleep1_C = wmean(C["sleep_followup"], C["n"])
    score1_T = wmean(T["score_followup"], T["n"])
    score1_C = wmean(C["score_followup"], C["n"])

    # ITT on change
    exp["sleep_change"] = exp["sleep_followup"] - exp["sleep_baseline"]
    exp["score_change"] = exp["score_followup"] - exp["score_baseline"]
    T2 = exp[exp["group"] == "T"].copy()
    C2 = exp[exp["group"] == "C"].copy()
    d_sleep_T = wmean(T2["sleep_change"], T2["n"])
    d_sleep_C = wmean(C2["sleep_change"], C2["n"])
    d_score_T = wmean(T2["score_change"], T2["n"])
    d_score_C = wmean(C2["score_change"], C2["n"])

    # Blocking by school on delta score
    blocked = []
    for school, g in exp.groupby("school"):
        t = g[g["group"] == "T"]
        c = g[g["group"] == "C"]
        eff = wmean(t["score_change"], t["n"]) - wmean(c["score_change"], c["n"])
        blocked.append(eff)
    blocked_avg = sum(blocked) / len(blocked)

    # Compliance
    pT = (T["n"] * T["compliance_rate"]).sum() / T["n"].sum()
    itt_sleep_change = d_sleep_T - d_sleep_C
    itt_score_change = d_score_T - d_score_C
    cace_sleep = itt_sleep_change / (pT - CONTAMINATION_PC)
    cace_score = itt_score_change / (pT - CONTAMINATION_PC)

    print("=== Handout computed answers (sanity check) ===")
    print(f"Population mean device sleep mu_pop = {mu_pop:.3f}")
    print(f"Convenience mean = {conv_mean:.3f}, bias = {conv_bias:.3f}")
    print(f"Voluntary mean = {vol_mean:.3f}, bias = {vol_bias:.3f}")
    print(f"Stratified mean self = {mu_self_strat:.3f}")
    print(f"Stratified mean device = {mu_dev_strat:.3f}")
    print(f"Overall response rate = {overall_resp_rate:.3f}")
    print(f"Post-stratified mean (respondents) = {mu_post:.3f}")
    print(f"Wording effect (leading-neutral) = {wording_diff:.3f}")
    print(f"ITT Sleep1 = {(sleep1_T - sleep1_C):.3f}")
    print(f"ITT Score1 = {(score1_T - score1_C):.3f}")
    print(f"ITT DeltaSleep = {(d_sleep_T - d_sleep_C):.3f}")
    print(f"ITT DeltaScore = {(d_score_T - d_score_C):.3f}")
    print(f"Blocked avg DeltaScore effect = {blocked_avg:.3f}")
    print(f"Compliance pT = {pT:.3f}, assumed pC = {CONTAMINATION_PC:.3f}")
    print(f"CACE DeltaSleep ≈ {cace_sleep:.3f}")
    print(f"CACE DeltaScore ≈ {cace_score:.3f}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```
